titleStmt.title: THE Historie of Troylus and Cresseida. As it was acted by the Kings Maiesties seruants at the Globe. Written by William Shakespeare

respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price with homographing and regularising completed by Alexis Antonia

publicationStmt.publisher: Imprinted by G. Eld for R. Bonian and H. Walley, and are to be sold at the spred Eagle in Paules Church-yeard, ouer against the great North doore.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Priam; King of Troy Hector; Son of Priam Troilus; Son of Priam Paris; Son of Priam Deiphobus; Son of Priam Helenus; Son of Priam Cassandra; Daughter of Priam; a Prophetess Margarelon; Bastard son of Priam Calchas; a Trojan priest Cressida; Daughter of Calchas Pandarus; Uncle of Cressida Andromache; Wife of Hector Multiple Speakers
Aeneas; Trojan commander Antenor; Trojan commander Agamemnon; the Greek General Menelaus; Brother of Agamemnon Achilles; Greek commander Ajax; Greek commander Ulysses; Greek commander Nestor; Greek commander Diomedes; Greek commander Patroclus; Greek commander Helen; Wife of Menelaus
Thersites; a Greek Alexander; Cressida's servant Servant to Troilus Servant to Paris Servant to Diomedes Myrmidon

div1.head: THE Famous Historie of Troylus and Cresseid. Excellently expressing the beginning of their loves, with the conceited wooing of Pandarus Prince of Licia.

div1.l: A never writer, to an ever
reader. News.
Eternal reader, you have here a new
play, never stal'd with the Stage,
never clapper-clawed with the palms
of the vulgar, and yet passing full of
the palm comical; for it is a birth of
your brain, that never undertook
any thing comical, vainly: And
were but the vain names of comedies changed for the
titles of Commodities, or of Plays for Pleas; you should
see all those grand censors, that now style them such
vanities, flock to them for the maine grace of their
gravities: especially this authors Comedies, that are
so framed to the life, that they serve for the most common Commentaries, of all the actions of our lives, shewingsuch a dexterity, and power of wit, that the most
displeased with Plays, are pleased with his Comedies.
And all such dull and heavy-witted worldlings, as were
never capable of the wit of a Comedy, coming by
report of them to his representations, have found that
wit there, that they never found in them-selves, and
have parted better witted then they came: feeling an
edge of wit set vpon them, more then ever they
dreamed they had brain to grind it on. So much and
such savoured salt of wit is in his Comedies, that they
seem (for their height of pleasure) to be borne in that
sea that brought forth Venus. Amongst all there is
none more witty then this: And had I time I would
comment vpon it, though I know it needs not, (for so
THE EPISTLE.
much as will make you think your testern well bestowed) but for so much worth, as even poor I know to be
stuffed in it. It deserves such a labour, as well as the best
Comedy in Terence or Plautus. And believe this,
that when he is gone, and his Comedies out of sale,
you will scramble for them, and set vp a new English
Inquisition. Take this for a warning, and at the peril
of your pleasures loss, and Judgments, refuse not, nor
like this the less, for not being sullied, with the smoky
breath of the multitude; but thank fortune for the
scape it hath made amongst you. Since by the grand
possessors wills I believe you should have prayed for them
rather then been prayed. And so I leave all such to be
prayed for (for the states of their wits healths)
that will not praise it.
Vale.

div1.head: The history of Troylus and Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: CAll here my varlet, I will unarm again,
Why should I war without the walls of Troy:
That find such cruel battle here within,
Each Troyan that is master of his heart,
Let him to field Troylus alas hath none.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Will this gear never be mended?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: The Greeks are strong and skilful to their strength
Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceness valiant,
But I am weaker than a woman's tear;
Tamer than sleep; fonder than ignorance,
Less valiant than the Virgin in the night,
And skilless as unpractised infancy:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well, I have told you enough of this; for my part I will
not meddle nor make no farther; he that will have a cake
out of the wheat must tarry the grinding.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Have I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Have I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Paude.
sp.p: Aye the bolting; but you must tarry the leavening.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Still have I tarried.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Aye, to the leavening, but hears yet in the word hereafter, the kneading, the making of the cake, the heating the
oven, and the baking, nay you must stay the cooling too, or
yea may chance burn your lips.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Patience herself, what Goddess ere she be,
Doth lesser blench at sufferance than I do:
At Priams royal table do I sit
And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,
So traitor then she comes when she is thence.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Well she looked yesternight fairer than ever I saw her
look, or any woman else.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I was about to tell thee when my heart,
As wedged with a sigh would rive in twain,
Lest Hector or my father should perceive me:
I have (as when the Sun doth light a scorn)
Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile,
But sorrow that is couched in seeming gladness,
Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
And her hair were not some-what darker than Hellens, well go to, there were no more comparison between
the women! but for my part she is my kinswoman, I would
not as they term it praise her, but I would somebody had
heard her talk yesterday as I did, I will not dispraise your
sister Cassandra's wit, but -------

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O Pandarus I tell thee Pandarus,
When I do tell thee there my hopes lie drowned
Reply not in how many fathoms deep,
They lie endrenched, I tell thee I am mad:
In Cressids love? thou answerest she is fair,
Powerest in the open ulcer of my heart:
Her eyes, her hair her cheek, her gate, her voice,
Handlest in thy discourse: O that her hand
In whose comparison all whites are ink
Writing their own reproach; to whose soft seizure,
The signets down is harsh, and spirit of sense:
Hard as the palm of ploughman; this thou tellest me,
As true thou tellest me, when I say I love her,
But saying thus in steed of oil and balm,
Thou layest in every gash that love hath given me
The knife that made it.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: I speak no more than truth.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Thou dost not speak so much.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
Faith I will not meddle in it, let her be as she is, if she
be fair it is the better for her, if she be not, she has the
mends in her own hands.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Good Pandarus, how now Pandarus?

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
I have had my labour for my travel, ill thought on
of her, and ill thought of you, gon between and between,
but small thanks for my labour.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: What art thou angry Pandarus? what with me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Because she is kin to me therefore she is not so fair
as Hellen, if she were kin to me, she would be as fair on Friday as Hellen, is on Sunday, but what I? I care not if she
were a blackamoor, it is all one to me.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Say I she is not fair?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I do not care whether you do or no, she is a fool to
stay behind her father, let her to the Greekes, and so I will tell
her the next time I see her for my part I will meddle nor make
no more in the matter.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Sweet Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Pray you speak no more to me I will leave all as I
found it and there an end.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Peace you ungracious clamours, peace rude sounds,
Fools on both sides, Helleu must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus,
I cannot fight upon this argument:
It is too starved a subject for my sword,
But Pandarus: O gods! how do you plague me
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar,
And he is as tetchy to be wood to woe,
As she is stubborn, chaste, against all suite.
Tell me Apollo for thy Daphues love
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India there she lies, a pearl,
Between our Ilium, and where she resides
Let it be called the wild and wandering flood:
Ourself the Merchant, and this sailing Pandar,
Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our bark.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: How now prince Troylus, wherefore not afield.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Because not there; this woman's answer sorts,
For womanish it is to be from thence.
What news Aeneas from the field today?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: That Paris is returned home and hurt.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By whom Aeneas?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Troylus by Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let Paris bleed it is but a scar to scorn,
Paris is gored with Menelaus horn.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Hark what good sport is out of town today.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Better at home, if would I might were may:
But to the sport abroad are you bound thither?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: In all swift haste.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come go we then together.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Who were those went by?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Queen Hecuba, and Hellen.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And whether go they?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Up to the Eastern tower,
Whose hight commands as subject all the vail,
To see the battle: Hector whose patience,
Is as a virtue fixed, today was moved:
He chid Andromache and struck his armourer,
And like as there were husbandry in war
Before the Sun rose, he was harnessed light,
And to the field goes he; where every flower
Did as a Prophet weep what it foresaw,
In Hectors wrath.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What was his cause of anger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The noise goes this, there is among the Greekes,
A Lord of Trojan blood, Nephew to Hector,
They call him Aiax.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good; and what of him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: They say he is a very man per se and stands alone.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: So do all men unless the are drunk, sick, or have no
legs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This man Lady, hath robbed many beasts of their particular additions, he is as valiant as the Lion, churlish as
the Bear, slow as the Elephant: a man into whom nature
hath so crowded humours, that his valour is crushed into folly,
his folly sauced with discretion: there is no man hath a virtue, that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint, but
he carries some stain of it. He is melancholy without cause
and merry against the hair, he hath the joints of everything,
but everything so out of joint, that he is a gouty
Briareus, many hands, and no use: or purblind Argus, all eyes,
and no sight.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
But how should this man that makes me smile, make
Hector angry.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p:
They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle
and stroke him down, the disdain and shame whereof
hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Who comes here.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: Madam your uncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Hectors a gallant man.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: As may be in the world Lady.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Whats that? whats that?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good morrow uncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Good morrow cozen Cressid: what do you talk of?
good morrow Alexander: how do you cozen? when were
you at Illum?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: This morning uncle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What were you talking of when I came? was Hector
armed and gon ere yea came to Illium, Hellen was not up
was she?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Hector was gone but Hellen was not up?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Even so, Hector was stirring early.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Was he angry?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: So he says here.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
True he was so; I know the cause too, he will lay about
him today I can tell them that, and there is Troylus will not come
far behind him, let them take heed of Troylus; I can tell
them that too.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What is he angry too?

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Who Troylus? Troylus is the better man of the two:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: O Iupiter there is no comparison.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
What not between Troylus and Hector? do you know
a man if you see him?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Aye, if I ever saw him before and knew him:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Well I say Troylus is Troylus:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Then you say as I say, for I am sure he is not Hector.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No nor Hector is not Troylus in some degrees.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: It is just, to each of them he is himself.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Himself, alas poor Troylus I would he were.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So he is.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Condition I had gone bare-foot to India.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: He is not Hector.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Himself? no? he is not himself, would he were himself, well the Gods are above, time must friend or end well
Troylus well, I would my heart were in her body; no, Hector
is not a better man than Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: He is elder.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Pardon me, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
The others not come to it, you shall tell me another
tale when the others come to it, Hector shall not have his
will this year.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: He shall not need it if he have his own.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nor his qualities.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nor his beauty.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: It would not become him, his own is better.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
You have no judgment niece; Hellen herself
swore the other day that Troylus for a brown favour (for so
it is I must confess) not brown neither.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: No, but brown.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Faith to say truth, brown and not brown.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: To say the truth, true and not true.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: She praised his complexion above Paris,

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Why Paris hath colour enough.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: So he has.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Then Troylus should have too much, if she praised
him above, his complexion is higher than his, he
having colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming
a praise for a good complexion, I had as lief Helens golden
tongue had commended Troylus for a copper nose.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I swear to you I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Then she is a merry greeke indeed.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Nay I am sure she does, she came to him the other
day into the compassed window, and you know he has not
past three or four hairs on his chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Indeed a Tapsters Arithmetic may soon bring
his particulars therein to a total.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Why he is very young, and yet will he within three
pound lift as much as his brother Hector.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Is he so young a man, and so old a lifter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
But to prove to you that Hellen loves him, she
came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Iuno have mercy, how came it cloven?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why, you know it is dimpled,
I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in
all Phrigia.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O he smiles valiantly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Does he not?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O yes, if it were a cloud in Autumn.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why go to then, but to prove to you that Hellen
loves Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Troylus will stand to thee proof if you will prove it so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Troylus, why he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle
head you would eat chickens in the shell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled
his chin, indeed she has a marvelous white hand I must needs
confess.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Without the rack.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on
his chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Alas poor chin many a wart is richer.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
But there was such laughing, Queen Hecuba laughed
that her eyes ran over.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: With millstones.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Cassandra laughed.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
But there was a more temperate fire under the pore
of her eyes: did her eyes run over too?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Hector laughed.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: At what was all this laughing.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Marry at the white hair that Hellen spied on Troylus chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
If it had been a green hair I should have
laughed too.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: They laughed not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

sp.speaker: Cres,
sp.p: What was his answer?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Quoth she here is but two and fifty heirs on your
chin; and one of them is white.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: This is her question.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is true, make no question of that, two and fifty
heirs quoth he, and one white, that white heir is my father, and all the rest are his sons. Iupiter quoth she, which
of these heirs is Paris my husband? the forked one quoth
he, plucked out and give it him: but there was such laughing,
and Hellen so blushed, and Paris so chaffed, and all the rest so
laughed that it past.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So let it now for it has been a great while going by.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Well cozen I told you a thing yesterday, think on it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So I do.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I will be sworn it is true, he will weep you if it were a
man born in April.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: And I will spring up in his tears if it were a nettle against May.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Hark they are coming from the field, shall we
stand up here and see them as they pass toward Ilion, good
Niece do, sweet Niece Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Here, here, here is an excellent place, here we may
see most bravely, I will tell you them all by their names, as they
pass by, but mark Troylus above the rest.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Speak not so loud.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is Aeneas, is not that a brave man, he is one of
the flowers of Troy I can tell you, but mark Troylus, you shall
see anon.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is Antenor, he has a shrewd wit I can tell you,
and he is man good enough, he is one of the soundest judgments in Troy whosoever, and a proper man of person, when
comes Troylus, I will show you Troylus anon, if he see me, you
shall see him nod at me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will he give you the nod:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You shall see:

sp.speaker: Crcs.
sp.p: If he do the rich shall have more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is Hector, that, that, look you that, there is a fellow! go thy way Hector, there is a brave man Niece, O brave
Hector, look how he looks, there is a countenance, is it not a
brave man?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O a brave man.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
Is he not? it does a man heart good, look you what
hacks are on his helmet, look you yonder, do you see, look
you there, there is no jesting, there is laying on, take it off, who will
as they say, there be hacks.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Be those with swords.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
Swords, anything he cares not, if the devil come to
him, its all one, by Gods lid it does ones heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris, look ye yonder
Niece, is it not a gallant man too, is it not, why this is brave now,
who said he came hurt home today. He is not hurt, why this
will do Hellens heart good now ha? would I could see Troylus now, you shall see Troylus anon.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That is Helenus, I marvel where Troylus is, that is Helenus, I think he went not forth today, that is Helenus.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: Can Helenus fight uncle?

sp.speaker: Pan:
Cres:
sp.p: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Panda:
sp.p:
Where? yonder? that is Deiphobus. It is Troylus!
there is a man Niece, hem? brave Troylus the Prince of
chivalry.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Peace for shame peace.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Mark him, note him: O brave Troylus, look well
upon him Niece, look you how his sword is bloodied, and
his helm more hacked than Hectors, and how he looks, and
how he goes? O admirable youth, he never saw three and
twenty, go thy way Troylus, go thy way, had I a sister were a
grace, or a daughter a Goddess, he should take his choice,
O admirable man! Paris? Paris is dirt to him, and I warrant
Hellen to change would give an eye to boot.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Here comes more.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Asses, fools, dolts, chaff and bran, chaff and bran, porridge
after meat, I could live and die in the eyes of Troylus, never
look, never look, the Eagles are gone, crows and daws,
crows and daws, I had rather be such a man as Troylus,
than Agamemnon and all Greece.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
There is amongst the Greekes Achilles a better
man than Troylus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Achilles, a dray-man, a porter, a very Camel.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Well, well:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well, well, why have you any discretion, have you
any eyes, do you know what a man is? is not birth, beauty,
good shape, discourse, man-hood, learning, gentleness, virtue youth, liberality and such like, the spice and salt that season a man.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Aye a minced man, and then to be baked with no date in
the pie, for then the man's date is out:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You are such a woman a man knows not at what
ward you lie:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p:
Upon my back to defend my belly, upon my wit
to defend my wiles, upon my secrecy to defend mine honesty, my mask to defend my beauty, and you to defend all
these: and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Say one of your watches.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Nay I will watch you for that; and that is one of the
chiefest of them two: If I cannot ward what I would not
have hit: I can watch you for telling how I took the blow
unless it swell past hiding, and then its past watching:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: You are such another:

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Sir my Lord would instantly speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: At your own house there he unarms him:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Good boy tell him I come, I doubt he be hurt, fare ye
well good Niece:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: Adiew uncle:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: I will be with you Niece by and by:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: To bring uncle:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Aye a token from Troylus:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: By the same token you are a Bawd,
sp.l: Words, vows, gifts, tears and loves full sacrifice:
He offers in another's enterprise,
But more in Troylus thousand fold I see,
Than in the glass of Pandars praise may be:
Yet hold I off: women are angels wooing,
"Things won are done, joys soul lies in the doing".
That she beloved, knows nought that knows not this,
"Men price the thing ungained more than it is",
That she was never yet that ever knew
Love got so sweet, as when desire did sue,
Therefore this maxim out of love I teach,
"Achievement is command; ungained beseech",
Then though my hearts content firm love doth bear,
Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

div2.stage: Enter Agamemnon. Nestor, Vlisses, Diomedes, Menelaus with others.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Princes: what grief hath set these Jaundice over your cheeks?
The ample proposition that hope makes,
In all designs begun on earth below,
Fails in the promised largeness, checks and disasters,
Grow in the veins of actions highest reared.
As knots by the conflux of meeting sap,
Infects the sound Pine, and diverts his grain,
Tortive and errant from his course of growth.
Nor Princes is it matter new to us,
That we come short of our suppose so far,
That after seven years siege, yet Troy walls stand,
Sith ever action that hath gone before,
Whereof we have record, trial did draw,
Bias and thwart: not answering the aim,
And that unbodied figure of the thought,
That gave it surmised shape: why then you Princes,
Do you with cheeks abashed behold our works,
And call them shames which are indeed nought else,
But the protractive trials of great Ioue,
To find persistive constancy in men.
The fineness of which metal is not found,
In fortunes love: for then the bold and coward,
The wise and fool, the Artist and unread,
The hard and soft seem all affined and kin,
But in the wind and tempest of her frown,
Distinction with a broad and powerful fan,
Puffing at all, winnows the light away,
And what hath mass or matter by itself,
Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: With due observance of the godlike seat,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance,
Lies the true proof of men: the sea being smooth,
How many shallow bauble boats dare sail,
Upon her ancient breast, making their way
With those of nobler bulk?
But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon, behold
The strong ribbed bark through liquid mountains cut,
Bounding between the two moist elements,
Like Perseus horse. Where is then the saucy boat,
Whose weak untimbered sides but even now
Corivalled greatness? either to harbour fled,
Or made a toast for Neptune: even so
Doth valours show, and valours worth divide
In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness
The herd hath more annoyance by the Breeze
Than by the Tiger, but when the splitting wind,
Makes flexible the knees of knotted Oaks,
And Flies fled under shade, why then the thing of courage,
As roused with rage, with rage doth sympathise,
And with an accent tuned in self same key,
Retires to chiding fortune.

sp.speaker: Uliss.
sp.l: Agamemnon,
Thou great Commander, nerves and bone of Greece,
Heart of our numbers, soul and only sprite,
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut up: hear what Vlisses speaks,
Besides the applause and approbation,
The which most mighty (for thy place and sway
And thou most reverend) for the stretched out life,
I give to both your speeches; which were such
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece,
Should hold up high in brass, and such again
As venerable Nestor (hatched in silver)
Should with a bond of air strong as the Axle-tree,
(On which heaven rides) knit all the Greekish ears
To his experienced tongue, yet let it please both
Thou great and wise, to hear Vlisses speak.
Troy yet upon his bases had been down,
And the great Hectors sword had lacked a master
But for these instances.
The speciality of rule hath been neglected,
And look how many Grecian tents do stand,
Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions,
When that the general is not like the hive,
To whom the foragers shall all repair,
What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded
The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask.
The heavens them-selves, the planets and this centre
Observe degree, priority and place,
In sisture, course, proportion, season, form,
Office and custom, in all line of order.
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol,
In noble eminence enthroned and sphered,
Amidst the other; whose medicinable eye,
Corrects the influence of evil Planets,
And posts like the Commandment of a King,
Sans check to good and bad. But when the Planets,
In evil mixture to disorder wander,
What plagues, and what portents, what mutiny?
What raging of the sea, shaking of earth?
Commotion in the winds, frights, changes, horrors
Divert and crack, rend and deracinate,
The unity and married calm of states
Quite from their fixture: O when degree is shaked,
Which is the ladder of all high designs,
The enterprise is sick. How could communities,
Degrees in schools, and brother-hoods in Cities,
Peaceful commerce from dividable shores,
The primogeniture and due of birth,
Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels,
But by degree stand in authentic place:
Take but degree away, untune that string,
And hark what discord follows, each thing melts
In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters
Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores,
And make a sop of all this solid globe:
Strength should be Lord of imbecility,
And the rude son should strike his father dead.
Force should be right or rather right and wrong,
(Between whose endless jar Justice resides)
Should loose their names, and so should Justice too?
Then everything include itself in power,
Power into will, will into appetite,
And appetite an universal Wolf,
(So doubly seconded with will and power)
Must make perforce an universal prey,
And last eat up himself.
Great Agamemnon,
This chaos when degree is suffocate,
Follows the choking,
And this neglection of degree it is,
That by a pace goes backward with a purpose
It hath to clime. The generals disdained,
By him one step below, he by the next,
That next by him beneath, so every step,
Exampled by the first pace that is sick
Of his superior, grows to an envious fever
Of pale and bloodless emulation,
And it is this fever that keeps Troy on foot,
Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakness stands not in her strength.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: Most wisely hath Vlisses here discovered,
The fever whereof all our power is sick.

sp.speaker: Agamem.
sp.l: The nature of the sickness found, Vlisses
What is the remedy?

sp.speaker: Ulisses.
sp.l: The great Achilles whom opinion crowns,
The sinew and the fore-hand of our host,
Having his ear full of his airy fame,
Grows dainty of his worth, and in his Tent
Lies mocking our designs: with him Patroclus
Upon a lazy bed the live long day,
Breaks scurril jests,
And with ridiculous and silly action,
Which (slanderer) he Imitation calls,
He pageants us. Some-time great Agamemnon,
Thy topless deputation he puts on,
And like a strutting Player, whose conceit
Lies in his ham-string, and doth think it rich
To here the wooden dialogue and sound,
Twixt his stretched footing and the scaffoldage,
Such to be pitied and over-rested seeming,
He acts thy greatness in. And when he speaks,
It is like a chime a mending, with terms unsquare,
Which from the tongue of roaring Typhoon dropped,
Would seem hyperboles, at this fusty stuff,
The large Achilles on his pressed bed lolling,
From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause,
Cries excellent; it is Agamemnon right,
Now play me Nestor, hem and stroke thy beard,
As he being dressed to some Oration,
That is done, as near as the extremest ends
Of parallels, as like as Uulcan and his wife:
Yet god Achilles still cries excellent,
It is Nestor right: now play him me Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night alarm,
And then forsooth the faint defects of age,
Must be the scæne of mirth, to cough and spit,
And with a palsy fumbling on his gorget,
Shake in and out the rivet, and at this sport
Sir valour dies, cries O enough Patroclus,
Or give me ribs of steel, I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleen, and in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures shapes,
Severals and generals of grace exact,
Achievements, plots, orders, preventions,
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Success or loss, what is, or is not, serves
As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: And in the imitation of these twain,
Who as Vlisses says opinion crowns,
With an imperial voice: many are infect,
Aiax is grown self-willed, and bears his head
In such a rein, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles: keeps his Tent like him,
Makes factious feasts, rails on our state of war,
Bold as an Oracle, and sets Thersites
A slave, whose gall coins slanders like a mint,
To match us in comparisons with dirt,
To weaken our discredit, our exposure
How rank soever rounded in with danger.

sp.speaker: Vlisses.
sp.l: They tax our policy, and call it cowardice,
Count wisdom as no member of the war,
Forestall prescience, and esteem no act
But that of hand, the still and mental parts,
That do contrive how many hands shall strike,
When fitness calls them on, and know by measure
Of their observant toil the enemies weight,
Why this hath not a fingers dignity,
They call this bed-work, mappery, Closet war,
So that the Ram that batters down the wall,
For the great swing and rudeness of his poise,
They place before his hand that made the engine,
Or those that with the finesse of their souls,
By reason guide his execution.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Let this be granted, and Achilles horse
Makes many Thetis sons,

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What trumpet? look Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What would you fore our tent.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Is this great Agamemnons tent I pray you?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Even this.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: May one that is a Herald and a Prince,
Do a fair message to his Kingly eyes?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: With surety stronger than Achilles arm,
Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice,
Call Agamemnon head and general.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Fair leave and large security, how may
A stranger to those most imperial looks,
Know them from eyes of other mortals?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Aye, I ask that I might waken reverence,
And bid the cheek be ready with a blush,
Modest as morning, when she coldly eyes the youthful Phœbus,
Which is that god, in office guiding men,
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: This Troyan scorns us, or the men of Troy,
Are ceremonious Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Æne,
sp.l: Courtiers as free as debonair, unarmed
As bending Angels, that is their fame in peace:
But when they would seem soldiers, they have galls,
Good arms, strong joints, true swords, and great Ioues accord
Nothing so full of heart: but peace Aeneas,
Peace Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips,
The worthiness of praise distains his worth,
If that the praised him-self bring the praise forth.
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath fame blows, that praise sole pure transcends.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Sir you of Troy, call you yourself Aeneas?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: aye Greeke, that is my name.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Whats your affairs I pray you?

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Sir pardon, it is for Agamemnons ears.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: He hears nought privately that comes from Troy.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper with him,
I bring a trumpet to awake his ear,
To set his seat on that attentive bent,
And then to speak.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Speak frankly as the wind,
It is not Agamemnons sleeping hour;
That thou shalt know Troyan he is awake,
He tells thee so himself.

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Trumpet blow aloud,
Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents,
And every Greeke of metal let him know,
What Troy means fairly, shall be spoke aloud.
We have great Agamemnon here in Troy,
A Prince called Hector, Priam is his father,
Who in his dull and long continued truce,
Is resty grown: He bad me take a Trumpet,
And to this purpose speak. Kings, Princes, Lords,
If there be one among the fairest of Greece,
That holds his honour higher than his ease,
And feeds his praise, more than he fears his peril,
That knows his valour, and knows not his fear,
That loves his Mistress more than in confession,
(With truant vows to her own lips he loves)
And dare avow her beauty, and her worth,
In other arms than hers: to him this challenge;
Hector in view of Troyans and of Greekes,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it:
He hath a Lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greeke did couple in his arms,
And will tomorrow with his Trumpet call,
Mid-way between your tents and walls of Troy,
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love:
If any come, Hector shall honour him:
If none, he will say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian dames are sun-burnt, and not worth
The splinter of a Lance. Even so much.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: This shall be told our lovers Lord Aeneas,
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home, but we are soldiers,
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love:
If then one is, or hath a means to be,
That one meets Hector: if none else I am he.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hectors grand-sire sucked. He is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian host,
A noble man that hath no spark of fire
To answer for his love, tell him from me,
I will hide my silver beard in a gold beaver,
And in my vambrace put my withered brawns
And meeting him tell him that my Lady,
Was fairer than his grandam, and as chaste,
As may be in the world, (his youth in flood)
I will prove this troth with my three drops of blood,

sp.speaker: Æne.
sp.l: Now heavens for-fend such scarcity of men.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Amen:
fair Lord Aeneas let me touch your hand,
To our pavilion shall I lead you sir;
Achilles shall have word of this intent,
So shall each Lord of Greece from tent to tent,
Yourself shall feast with us before you go,
And find the welcome of a noble foe.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Nestor.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What says Vlisses?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I have a young conception in my brain,
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: Blunt wedges rive hard knots, the seeded pride,
That hath to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles, must or now be cropped,
Or shedding breed a nursery of like evil,
To over-bulk us all.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Well and how?

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,
How ever it is spread in general name
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: True the purpose is perspicuous as substance,
Whose grossness little characters sum up:
And in the publication make no strain,
But that Achilles wear his brain, as barren,
As banks of libia (though Apollo knows
It is dry enough) will with great speed of judgment,
Aye with celerity find Hectors purpose, pointing on him.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: And wake him to the answer think you?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Why it is most meet; who may you else oppose,
That can from Hector bring those honours off,
If not Achilles: though it be a sportful combat,
Yet in the trial much opinion dwells:
For here the Troyans taste our dearest repute,
With their finest palate, and trust to me Ulisses
Our imputation shall be oddly poised
In this vild action, for the success,
Although particular shall give a scantling
Of good or bad unto the general,
And in such indexes (although small pricks
To their subsequent volumes) there is seen,
The baby figure of the giant mass,
Of things to come at large: It is supposed
He that meets Hector, issues from our choice,
And choice (being mutual act of all our souls)
Makes merit her election, and doth boyle,
(As it were from forth us all) a man distilled
Out of our vertues, who miscarrying,
What heart receives from hence a conquering part,
To steel a strong opinion to themselves.

sp.speaker: Uliss.
sp.l: Give pardon to my speech? therefore it is meet,
Achilles meet not Hector, let us like Merchants
First show foul wares, and think perchance they will sell;
If not; the luster of the better shall exceed,
By showing the worse first: do not consent,
That ever Hector and Achilles meet,
For both our honour and our shame in this, are dogged with
two strange followers.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I see them not with my old eyes what are they?

sp.speaker: Vless.
sp.l: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector
Were he not proud, we all should share with him:
But he already is too insolent.
And it were better parch in Afrique Sun,
Than in the pride and sault scorn of his eyes
Should he scape Hector fair. If he were foiled,
Why then we do our maine opinion crush
In taint of our best man. No, make a lottery
And by devise let blockish Aiax draw
The sort to fight with Hector, among ourselves,
Give him allowance for the better man,
For that will physic the great Myrmidon,
Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall,
His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends,
If the dull brainless Aiax come safe off
We will dress him up in voices, if he fail
Yet go we under our opinion still,
That we have better men, but hit or miss,
Our projects life this shape of sense assumes
Aiax employed plucks down Achilles plumes.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now Vlisses I begin to relish thy advice,
And I will give a taste thereof forthwith,
To Agamemnon, go we to him straight
Two curs shall tame each other, pride alone
Must arre the mastiffs on, as it were a bone.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Agamemnon, how if he had biles, full, all over, generally.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: And those biles did run (say so), did not the general run then, were not that a botchy core.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Dog.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Then would come some matter from him, I see none
now.

sp.speaker: Aia:
sp.p: Thou bitch-wolf's son canst thou not hear, feele then.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
The plague of Greece upon thee thou mongrel beef
witted Lord.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
Speak then thou unsalted leaven, speak, I will beat
thee into handsomeness.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness, but I
think thy horse will sooner con an oration without
book, than thou learn prayer without book, thou canst
strike canst thou? a red murrion hath thy Jades tricks.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Toad-stool? learn me the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p:
Doest thou think I have no sense thou strikest me
thus?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: The proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Thou art proclaimed fool I think.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Do not Porpentin, do not, my fingers itch:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I would thou didst itch from head to foot, and I had
the scratching of the, I would make thee the loathsomest scab
in Greece, when thou art forth in the incursions thou strikest
as slow as another.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I say the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles, and thou art as full of envy at his greatness, as Cerberus
is at Proserpinas beauty, Aye that thou barkest at him.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Mistress Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou shouldst strike him. Aiax Coblofe,

He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a sailor
breaks a biscuit, you whoreson cur. Do? do?

sp.speaker: Aiax:
sp.p: Thou stool for a witch:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Aye, Do? do? thou sodden witted Lord, thou hast
no more brain than I have in mine elbows, an Asinico
may tutor thee, you scurvy valiant ass, thou art here but to
thrash Troyans, and thou art bought and sold among those
of any wit, like a Barbarian slave. If thou use to beat me I
will begin at thy heel, and tell what thou art by inches,
thou thing of no bowels thou.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: You dog:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You scurvy Lord.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: You cur.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Mars his Idiot, do rudeness, do Camel, do, do.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Why how now Aiax wherefore do ye thus,
How now Thersites whats the matter man.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You see him there? do you?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Aye whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Nay look upon him.

sp.speaker: Achil:
sp.p: So I do, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Nay but regard him well.

sp.speaker: Achil:
sp.p: Well, why so I do.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p:
But yet you look not well upon him, for whosomeever
you take him to be he is Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: I know that fool.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Aye but that fool knows not himself.

sp.speaker: Aiax:
sp.p: Therefore I beat thee.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p:
Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters, his evasions have ears thus long, I have bobbed his brain more than
he has beat my bones. It will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow: this Lord (Achilles) Aiax, who wears his wit in his belly, and his guts in his head, I tell you what I say of him.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I say this Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Nay good Aiax.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Has not so much wit.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Nay I must hold you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
As will stop the eye of Hellens needle, for whom
he comes to fight.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Peace fool?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I would have peace and quietness, but the fool
will not, he there, that he: look you there?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: O thou damned cur I shall-------------

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Will you set your wit to a fools.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: No I warrant you, the fools will shame it.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Good words Thesites.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Whats the quarrel.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
I bad the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the
proclamation, and he rails upon me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serve thee not?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Well, go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serve here voluntary.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Your last service was sufferance: it was not voluntary,
no man is beaten voluntary, Aiax was here the voluntary,
and you as under an Impress.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Even so, a great deal of your wit too, lies in your
sinews, or else there be liars, Hector shall have a great
catch and knock at either of your brains, he were as good
crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What with me too Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
There is Vlisses and old Nestor, whose wit was mouldy
ere their grandsires had nails, yoke you like draught oxen,
and make you plough up the wars.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Yes good sooth, to Achilles, to Aiax, to ------------

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I shall cut out your tongue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: It is no matter, I shall speak as much as thou afterwards.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: No more words Thersites peace.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I will hold my peace when Achilles brooch bids me, shall I?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: There is for you Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I will see you hanged like Clot-poles, ere I come any
more to your tents, I will keep where there is wit stirring,
and leave the faction of fools.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: A good riddance.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Marry this sir is proclaimed through all our host,
That Hector by the first hour of the Sun:
Will with a trumpet twixt our Tents and Troy,
Tomorrow morning call some Knight to arms,
That hath a stomach, and such a one that dare,
Maintain I know not what, (it is trash) farewell -------

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Farewell, who shall answer him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I know not, it is put to lottery, otherwise,
He knew his man.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: O meaning you? I will go learn more of it.

div2.stage: Enter Priam, Hector, Troylus, Paris and Helenus.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent,
Thus once again says Nestor from the Greckes:
Deliver Hellen, (and all damage else,
As honour, loss of time, travel, expense,
Wounds, friends and what else dear that is consumed:
In hot digestion of this cormorant war)
Shall be stroke off, Hector what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Hect:
sp.l: Though no man lesser fears the Greekes than I
As far as toucheth my particular: yet dread Priam
There is no Lady of more softer bowels,
More spongy to suck in the sense of fear:
More ready to cry out, who knows what follows
Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surely
Surely secure, but modest doubt is called
The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches,
To the bottom of the worst let Hellen go,
Since the first sword was drawn about this question
Every tithe soul amongst many thousand dismes,
Hath been as dear as Hellen. I mean of ours:
If we have lost so many tenths of ours,
To guard a thing not ours, nor worth to us,
(Had it our name) the value of one ten,
What merits in that reason which denies,
The yielding of her up?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my brother,
Weigh you the worth and honour of a King:
So great as our dread fathers in a scale
Of common ounces? will you with Compters sum,
The past proportion of his infinite
And buckle in, a waste most fathomless,
With spans and inches so diminutive:
As fears and reasons: Fie for Godly shame?

sp.speaker: Hele.
sp.l: No marvel though you bite so sharpe of reasons,
You are so empty of them should not our father;
Bear the great sway of his affairs with reason,
Because your speech hath none that tell him so?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You are for dreams and slumbers brother Priest,
You fur your gloves with reason, here are your reasons
You know an enemy intends you harm:
You know a sword employed is perilous
And reason flies the object of all harm.
Who marvels then when Helenus beholds,
A Grecian and his sword, if he do set
The very wings of reason to his heels,
And fly like chidden Mercury from Ioue
Or like a star disorbd? nay if we talk of reason,
Sets shut our gates and sleep: man-hood and honour,
Should have hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts
With this crammed reason, reason and respect,
Make livers pale, and lustihood deject.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Brother, she is not worth, what she doth cost the
keeping.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Whats aught but as it is valued.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: But value dwells not in particular will,
It holds his estimate and dignity,
As well wherein it is precious of itself
As in the prizer, it is mad Idolatry
To make the service greater than the God,
And the will dotes that is attributive;
To what infectiously itself affects,
Without some image of the affected merit,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I take today a wife, and my election:
Is led on in the conduct of my will,
My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,
Two traded pilots twixt the dangerous shore,
Of will and Judgment: how may I avoid?
(Although my will distaste what it elected)
The wife I choose, there can be no evasion,
To blench from this and to stand firm by honour,
We turn not back the silks upon the merchant
When we have soiled them, nor the remainder viands,
We do not throw in unrespective sieve,
Because we now are full, it was thought meet
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greekes.
Your breath with full consent bellied his sails,
The seas and winds (old wranglers) took a truce:
And did him service, he touched the ports desired,
And for an old aunt whom the Greekes held Captive,
He brought a Grecian Queen, whose youth and freshness,
Wrinkles Apolloes, and makes pale the morning.
Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our Aunt,
Is she worth keeping? why she is a pearl,
Whose price hath launched above a thousand ships:
And turned crowned Kings to Merchants,
If you will avouch it was wisdom Paris went,
As you must needs, for you all cried go, go,
If you will confess he brought home worthy prize:
As you must needs, for you all, clapped your hands,
And cried inestimable: why do you now
The issue of your proper wisdoms rate,
And do a deed that never fortune did,
Beggar the estimation, which you prized
Richer than sea and land? O theft most base,
That we have stolen, what we do fear to keep,
But thieves unworthy of a thing so stolen:
That in their country did them that disgrace,
We fear to warrant in our native place.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troyans cry:

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: What noise? what shrike is this?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: It is our mad sister I do know her voice,

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troyans.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: It is Cassandra!

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troyans cry, lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Peace sister peace.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Virgins, and boys, mid-age, and wrinkled elders,
Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry,
Add to my clamours: let us pay be-times
A moiety of that mass of moan to come:
Cry Troyans cry, practise your eyes with tears,
Troy must not be, nor goodly I lion stand.
Our fire-brand brother Paris burns us all,
Cry Troyans cry, a Helen and a woe,
Cry, cry, Troy burns, or else let Hellen go.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now youthful Troylus, do not these high strains
Of divination in our Sister, work
Some touches of remorse? or is your blood
So madly hot, that no discourse of reason,
Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,
Can qualify the same?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Why brother Hector,
We may not think the justness of each act
Such, and no other than event doth form it,
Nor once deject the courage of our minds,
Because Cassandra's mad, her brain-sick raptures
Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel,
Which hath our several honours all engaged,
To make it gracious. For my private part,
I am no more touched than all Priams sons:
And Ioue forbid there should be done amongst us,
Such things as might offend the weakest spleen,
To fight for and maintain.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Else might the world convince of levity,
As well my under-takings as your counsels,
But I attest the gods, your full consent,
Gave wings to my propension, and cut off
All fears attending on so dire a project,
For what (alas) can these my single arms?
What propugnation is in one man's valour
To stand the push and enmity of those
This quarrel would excite? Yet I protest
Were I alone to pass the difficulties,
And had as ample power, as I have will,
Paris should never retract, what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuit,

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Paris you speak
Like one be-sotted on your sweet delights,
You have the honey still, but these the gall,
So to be valiant, is no praise at all.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sir, I propose not merely to myself,
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it,
But I would have the soil of her fair rape,
Wiped off in honourable keeping her,
What treason were it to the ransacked queen,
Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me,
Now to deliver her possession up
On terms of base compulsion? can it be,
That so degenerate a strain as this,
Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?
There is not the meanest spirit on our party,
Without a heart to dare, or sword to draw,
When Helen is defended: nor none so noble,
Whose life were ill bestowed, or death unfamed,
Where Helen is the subject. Then I say,
Well may we fight for her, whom we know well,
The worlds large spaces cannot parallel.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Paris and Troylus, you have both said well,
And on the cause and question now in hand,
Have glozed, but superficially, not much
Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Unfit to here Moral Philosophy;
The reasons you allege, do more conduce
To the hot passion of distempered blood,
Than to make up a free determination
Twixt right and wrong: for pleasure and revenge,
Have ears more deaf than Adders to the voice
Of any true decision. Nature craves
All dues be rendered to their owners. Now
What nearer debt in all humanity,
Than wife is to the husband? if this law
Of nature be corrupted through affection
And that great minds of partial indulgence,
To their benumbed wills resist the same,
There is a law in each well-ordered nation,
To curb those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refractory;
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's King,
As it is known she is, these moral laws
Of nature and of nations, speak aloud
To have her back returned: thus to persist
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heavy. Hectors opinion
Is this in way of truth: yet never the less,
My sprightly brethren, I propend to you
In resolution to keep Helen still,
For it is a cause that hath no mean dependence,
Upon our joint and several dignities.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Why there you touched the life of our design:
Were it not glory that we more affected,
Than the performance of our heaving spleens,
I would not wish a drop of Troyan blood,
Spent more in her defence. But worthy Hector,
She is a theme of honour and renown,
A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may beat down our foes,
And fame in time to come canonise us,
For I presume brave Hector would not loose
So rich advantage of a promised glory,
As smiles upon the fore-head of this action,
For the wide worlds revenue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I am yours,
You valiant offspring of great Priamus,
I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dull and factious nobles of the Greekes,
Will shrike amazement to their drowsy spirits,
I was advertised, their great general slept,
Whilst emulation in the army crept:
This I presume will wake him.

sp.p:
How now Thersites? what lost in the Labyrinth of thy
fury? shall the Elephant Aiax carry it thus? he beats me,
and I rail at him: O worthy satisfaction, would it were
otherwise: that I could beat him, whilst he railed at me:
'sfoot, I will learn to conjure and raise Devils, but I will see
some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there is Achilles, a
rare engineer. If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of them-selves.
O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou
art Ioue the king of gods: and Mercury, loose all the Serpentine craft of thy Caduceus, if ye take not that little
little less than little wit from them that they have:
which short-armed Ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from
a spider, without drawing their massy Irons, and cutting
the web. After this the vengeance on the whole camp,
or rather the Neopolitan bone-ache: for that methinks is
the curse depending on those that war for a placket. I
have said my prayers, and devil Envy say Amen. What ho
my Lord Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patrocl.
sp.p:
Who is there? Thersites? good Thersites come
in and rail.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p:
If I could a remembered a guilt counterfeit, thou
couldst not have slipped out of my contemplation: but it is no
matter, thyself upon thyself. The common curse of mankind, Folly and Ignorance, be thine in great revenue: Heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near
thee. Let thy blood be thy direction till thy death: then if
she that lays thee out says thou art not a fair course, I will
be sworn and sworn upon it, she never shrouded any but
lazars. Amen. Where is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: What art thou devout? wast thou in prayer?

sp.speaker: Thers.
sp.p: Aye the heavens hear me.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thersites, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Where? where? O where? art thou come why my
cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself into
my table, so many meals, come what is Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Thy commander Achilles, then tell me Patroclus,
whats Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p:
Thy Lord Thersites. Then tell me I pray thee,
what is Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me Patroclus,
what art thou?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thou must tell that knowest.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: O tell, tell.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I will decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my Lord, I am Patroclus knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Derive this? come?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a fool to be commanded. Thersites is a fool
to serve such a fool, and this Patroclus is a fool positive.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Why am I a fool?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Make that demand of the Prover, it suffices me
thou art: look you, who comes here?

div2.stage: Enter Agam: Vliss: Nestor, Diomed, Aiax & Calcas.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Come Patroclus, I will speak with nobody: come
in with me Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery: all the argument is a whore, and a Cuckold, a good
quarrel to draw emulous factions, and bleed to death upon.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Where is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Within his tent, but ill disposed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let it be known to him, that we are here,
He sate our messengers and we lay by,
Our appertainings, visiting of him
Let him be told so, lest perchance he think,
We dare not move the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: I shall say so to him.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: We saw him at the opening of his tent,
He is not sick.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
Yes Lion sick, sick of proud heart, you may call it
melancholy if you will favour the man. But by my head it is
pride: but why, why, let him show us a cause?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: What moves Aiax thus to bay at him?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: Achillis hath inveigled his fool from him,

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Who Thersites?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: He.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Then will Aiax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

sp.speaker: Vli.
sp.p:
No, you see he is his argument, that has his argument
Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p:
All the better, their fraction is more our wish than their
faction, but it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.

sp.speaker: Vli.
sp.p:
The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie,
Here comes Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: No Achilles with him.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p:
The Elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy,
His legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles bids me say he is much sorry,
If anything more than your sport and pleasure
Did move your greatness, and this noble state,
To call upon him. He hopes it is no other
But for your health, and your digestion sake,
An after dinners breath.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Here you Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with these answers,
But his evasion winged thus swift with scorn,
Cannot out-fly our apprehensions,
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason
Why we ascribe it to him. Yet all his vertues,
Not virtuously on his own part beheld,
Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss,
Yea like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,
Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him,
We come to speak with him, and you shall not sin,
If you do say, we think him over-proud
And under-honest: in self assumption greater
Than in the note of judgment. And worthier than himself
Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on
Disguise, the holy strength of their command,
And under-write in an observing kind,
His humorous predominance: yea watch
His course, and time, his ebbs and flows, and if
The passage, and whole stream of his commencement,
Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,
That if he over-hold his price so much,
We will none of him. But let him like an engine,
Not portable, lie under this report.
Bring action hither, this cannot go to war,
A stirring dwarf we do allowance give,
Before a sleeping giant. Tell him so.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: I shall, and bring his answer presently.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: In second voice we will not be satisfied,
We come to speak with him: Vlisses entertain.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: What is he more than another.

sp.speaker: Agam,
sp.p: No more than what he thinks he is.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Is he so much: do you not think he thinks himself a better man than I am?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p:
No noble Aiax, you are as strong, as valiant, as
wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether
more tractable.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
Why should a man be proud? how doth pride grow?
I know not what pride is.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p:
Your mind is the clearer, and your vertues the
fairer, he that is proud eats up him-self: Pride is his
own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle, and
what ever praises itself but in the deed, devours the
deed in the praise.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
I do hate a proud man, as I do hate the engendering
of Toads.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: And yet he loves himself, is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Whats his excuse?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: He doth rely on none.
But carries on the stream of his dispose,
Without observance, or respect of any,
In will peculiar, and in self admission.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Why will he not upon our fair request,
Untent his person, and share the air with us.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Things small as nothing, for requests sake only,
He makes important, possessed he is with greatness,
And speaks not to himself but with a pride,
That quarrels at self breath. Imagined worth,
Holds in his blood such swollen and hot discourse,
That twixt his mental and his active parts,
Kingdomed Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters down himself. What should I say,
He is so plaguey proud, that the death tokens of it,
Cry no recovery.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Let Aiax go to him,
Dear Lord, go you, and greet him in his tent,
It is said he holds you well, and will be led,
At your request a little from himself.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: O Agamemnon let it not be so,
We will consecrate the steps that Aiax makes,
When they go from Achilles: shall the proud Lord
That basts his arrogance with his own seam,
And never suffers matter of the world
Enter his thoughts, save such as doth revolve,
And ruminate him-self: shall he be worshipped,
Of that we hold an idol more than he,
No: this thrice worthy and right valiant Lord,
Shall not so stall his palm nobly acquired,
Nor by my will assubjugate his merit,
As amply liked as Achilles is, by going to Achilles,
That were to enlard his fat already pride,
And add more coals to Cancer when he burns,
With entertaining great Hiperion,
This Lord go to him. Iupiter forbid,
And say in thunder Achilles go to him.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: O this is well, he rubs the vain of him.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: And how his silence drinks up his applause,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If I go to him: with my armed fist I will push him over the face.

sp.speaker: Agam
sp.l: O no, you shall not go,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If he be proud with me, I will feeze his pride,
Let me go to him.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: A paltry insolent fellow.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: How he describes himself.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Can he not be sociable.

sp.speaker: Uliss.
sp.p: The Raven chides blackness.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I will tell his humorous blood.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: He will be the physician, that should be the patient.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: And all men were of my mind.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: Wit would be out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Aiax:
sp.p:
He should not bear it so, he should eat swords first?
shall pride carry it?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: And two'od you would carry half.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: He would have ten shares.
I will knead him, I will make him supple, he is not yet through warm?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p:
Force him with prayers pour in, pour, his ambition
is dry.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: My Lord you feed too much on this dislike.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Our noble general do not do so?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: Why it is this naming of him does him harm,
Here is a man but it is before his face, I will be silent.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Wherefore should you so?
He is not emulous as Achilles is.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Know the whole world he is as valiant -------------

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
A whoreson dog that shall palter with us thus, would
he were a Troyan?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What a vice were it in Aiax now:

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: If he were proud.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Or covetous of praise.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Aye or surly born.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Or strange or self affected.

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: Thank the heavens Lord, thou art of sweet composure
Praise him that begat thee, she that gave thee suck:
Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature,
Thrice famed beyond all thy erudition:
But he that disciplined thine arms to fight,
Let Mars divide eternity in twain,
And give him half, and for thy vigour:
Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield,
To sinewy Aiax, I will not praise thy wisdom,
Which like a board: a pale, a shore confines
This spacious and dilated parts, here is Nestor,
Instructed by the antiquary times:
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise,
But pardon father Nestor were your days
As green as Aiax, and your brain so tempered,
You should not have the eminence of him,
But be as Aiax.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Shall I call you father?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Aye my good Son.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Be ruled by him Lord Aiax.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: There is no tarrying here the Hart Achilles,
Keeps thicket, please it our great general,
To call together all his state of war,
Fresh Kings are come to Troy. Tomorrow
We must with all our maine of power stand fast,
And here is a Lord come Knights from East to West
And call their flower, Aiax shall cope the best.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Go we to counsel, let Achilles sleep,
Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Friend you, pray you a word, do you not follow the
young Lord Paris.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Aye sir when he goes before me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You depend upon him I mean.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir I do depend upon the Lord.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You depend upon a notable gentleman I must needs
praise him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Lord be praised?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You know me? do you not?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith sir superficially.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I hope I shall know your honour better?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do desire it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are in the state of grace?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Grace? not so friend, honour and Lordship are my titles, what music is this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I do but partly know sir, it is music in parts.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Know you the musicians?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wholly sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who play they to?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To the hearers sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: At whose pleasure friend?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At mine sir, and theirs that love music.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Command I mean:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who shall I command sir?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend we understand not one another, I am too courtly and thou too cunning, at whose request do these men play?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
That is to it indeed sir? marry sir, at the request of Paris my Lord, who is there in person, with him the mortal
Venus, the heart blood of beauty, loves invisible soul:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who my cozen Cressida.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No sir, Hellen, could not you find out that by her attributes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
It should seem fellow thou hast not seen the Lady
Cressid I come to speak with Paris, from the Prince Troylus. I will make a complemental assault upon him for my
business seethes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sodden business, there is a stewed phrase indeed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Fair be to you my Lord, and to all this fair company,
fair desires in all fair measure fairly guide them, especially
to you fair Queen fair thoughts be your fair pillow.

sp.speaker: Hel
sp.p: Dear Lord you are full of fair words:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You speak your fair pleasure sweet Queen,
Fair Prince here is good broken music.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You have broke it cozen: and by my life you shall
make it whole again, you shall piece it out with a piece of
your performance.
Nel. he is full of harmony:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Truly Lady no:

sp.speaker: Hel:
sp.p: O sir:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Rude in sooth, in good sooth very rude.

sp.speaker: Paris:
sp.p: Well said my Lord, well, you say so in fits:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I have business to my Lord dear Queen? my Lord
will you vouchsafe me a word.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Nay this shall not hedge us out, we will hear you sing
certainly:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
Well sweet Queen you are pleasant with me, but,
marry thus my Lord my dear Lord, and most esteemed
friend your brother Troylus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My Lord Pandarus honey sweet Lord,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Go to sweet Queen, go to?
Commends himself most affectionately to you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
You shall not bob us out of our melody,
If you do our melancholy upon your head.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sweet Queen, sweet Queen, that is a sweet Queen
I'faith ----------

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And to make a sweet Lady sad is a sour offence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Nay that shall not serve your turn, that shall it not
in truth la? Nay I care not for such words, no, no. And my
Lord he desires you that if the King call for him at super.
You will make his excuse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What says my sweet Queenem, my very very sweet
Queen?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What exploit's in hand, where sups he tonight?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Nay but my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p:
What says my sweet Queen? my cozen will fall out
with you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: You must not know where he sups.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I will lay my life with my disposer Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
No, no? no such matter you are wide, come your
disposer is sick.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well I will makes excuse?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Aye good my Lord, why should you say Cresseida, no,
your disposers sick.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I spy?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You spy? what do you spy? come, give me an instrument, now sweet Queen:

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why this is kindly done?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
My Niece is horribly in love with a thing you have
sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
She shall have it my Lord, if it be not my Lord
Paris.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
He? no? she will none of him, they two are
twain.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Falling in after falling out may make them three.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Come, come, I will hear no more of this, I will sing you a
song now.

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p:
Aye, Aye, prithee, now by my troth sweet lad thou hast a
fine fore-head.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Aye you may, you may.

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p:
Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all. O
Cupid, Cupid, Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Love? Aye that it shall i'faith.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: Aye good now love, love, nothing but love.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Love, love, nothing but love, still love still more:
For o loves bow. Shoots Buck and Do.
The shafts confound not that it wounds
But tickles still the sore:
These lovers cry, O ho they die,
Yet that which seems the wound to kill,
Doth turn O ho, to ha ha he,
So dying love lives still,
O ho a while, but ha ha ha,
O ho groans out for ha ha ha ---- hey ho,

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p: In love I'faith to the very tip of the nose.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
He eats nothing but doves love, and that breeds hot
blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts
beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Is this the generation of love: hot blood hot
thoughts and hot deeds, why they are vipers, is love a generation of vipers:
Sweet Lord whose afield today?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p:
Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Anthenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would fain have armed today, but my Nell
would not have it so.
How chance my brother Troylus went not?

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p:
He hangs the lip at something, you know all Lord
Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Not I honey sweet Queen, I long to hear how
they sped today:
You will remember your brothers excuse?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: To a hair.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Farewell sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Commend me to your niece.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I will sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: They are come from the field: let us to Priames Hall
To greet the warriors. Sweet Hellen I must woe you,
To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn buckles
With this your white enchanting fingers touched;
Shall more obey than to the edge of steel,
Or force of Greekish sinews: you shall do more
Than all the Island Kings, disarm great Hector.

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.l: It will make us proud to be his servant Paris?
Yea what he shall receive of us in duty,
Gives us more palm in beauty than we have.
Yea over-shines ourself.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Sweet above thought I love her?

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: How now where is thy master, at my Cousin Cressidas?

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: No sir stays for you to conduct him thither.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: O here he comes? how now, how now?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Sirrah walk off.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Have you seen my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: No Pandarus, I stalk about her door
Like to a strange soul upon the Stygian banks
Staying for waftage. O be thou my Charon.
And give me swift transportance to these fields,
Where I may wallow in the lily beds
Proposed for the deserver. O gentle Pandar,
From Cupids shoulder pluck his painted wings,
And fly with me to Cressid.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Walk here in the Orchard, I will bring her straight.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round,
The imaginary relish is so sweet,
That it enchants my sense: what will it be
When that the watery palates taste indeed
Loves thrice reputed Nectar? Death I fear me
Sounding destruction, or some joy too fine,
Too subtle, potent, tuned too sharp in sweetness
For the capacity of my ruder powers;
I fear it much, and I do fear besides
That I shall loose distinction in my joys
As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps
The enemy flying.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
She is making her ready, she will come straight, you
must be witty now, she does so blush, and fetches her wind so
short as if she were afraid with a spirit: I will fetch her; it is the
prettiest villain, she fetches her breath as short as a new taken
sparrow.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom,
My heart beats thicker than a feavorous pulse,
And all my powers do their bestowing loose
Like vassalage at unawares encountering
the eye of majesty.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Come, come, what need you blush?
Shames a baby; here she is now, swear the oaths now to
her that you have sworn to me: what are you gone again,
you must be watched ere you be made tame, must you? come
your ways come your ways, if you draw backward we will
put you in the fills: why do you not speak to her. Come
draw this curtain, and let us see your picture; alas the day?
how loath you are to offend daylight; if it were dark you would
close sooner: so so, rub on and kiss the mistress; how now
a kiss in fee-farm: build there Carpenter, the air is sweet.
Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you. The falcon, as the tercel: for all the ducks in the river: go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.p: You have bereft me of all words Lady.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Words pay no debts; give her deeds: but she will bereave you in the deeds too if she call your activity in question:
what billing again: here is in witness whereof the parties interchangeably. Come in come in I will go get a fire?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will you walk in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: O Cressed how often have I wished me thus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Wished my Lord? the gods grant? O my Lord?
